citeinfo.title: Changes in Anthropogenic Influences on Streams and Rivers: Land Use in Riparian Zones

descript.abstract: This dataset consists of five tables of data representing land use within riparian zones for five time steps for the period 1974-2012 (from the NAWQA Wall-to-Wall Anthropogenic Landuse Trends (NWALT) dataset), for Hydrologic Unit Code 10 (HUC-10) areas. The riparian zone is defined as all areas which are within 200-meter (m) flow distance of NHDPlus V2.1 networked streams and water bodies.
descript.purpose: These data are intended to provide a framework in which watershed-specific studies of water quality in streams and rivers may be analyzed. The focus of the data is on anthropogenic changes over time.
descript.supplinf: Five comma-separated text files are given here, one for each year of the NWALT product. Each file contains a "uniqid" field, which is the link to the data in other datasets in this product. The files represent HUC-10 areas and have 15,458 rows. The NWALT data are derived from Falcone, 2016 ("Enhanced Grazing Potential" version), which is in turn a slight modification of the product in Falcone, 2015. The only difference is that the 2016 product has some pixels which were classified as "Low Use" (class 50) in the original, reclassified as "Grazing Potential" (class 46). They are otherwise identical. Of the 15,458 rows, 38 are filled with "NA" in place of a numeric value because NHDPlus networked streamlines and water bodies did not extend into the HUC-10, and thus no "riparian zones" existed. Users should be attentive to these records when joining. Citations for HUC-10 boundaries: National Resources Conservation Service, 2017. References: Falcone, J.A., 2015, U.S. conterminous wall-to-wall anthropogenic land use trends (NWALT), 1974-2012. U.S. Geological Survey Data Series 948, 33 p. plus appendices 3-6 as separate files, http://dx.doi.org/10.3133/ds948. Falcone, J.A., 2016, Mapping enhanced grazing potential based on the NAWQA Wall-to-wall Anthropogenic Land-use Trends (NWALT) product, 1974-2012: U.S. Geological Survey data release, http://dx.doi.org/10.5066/F7CR5RFF. McKay, L., Bondelid, T., Dewald, T., Johnston, C., Moore, R., and Rea, A., 2012, NHDPlus Version 2: User Guide, 2012, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, available at: www.horizon-systems.com/NHDPlus/index.php. National Resources Conservation Service, 2017, Watershed boundary dataset (WBD): National Resources Conservation Service, U.S. Department of Agriculture, available at https://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/main/national/technical/nra/geo/, accessed January 9, 2018 from https://nrcs.app.box.com/v/huc/folder/39640323180. Price, C. V., Nakagaki, Naomi, and Hitt, K. J., 2012, National Water-Quality Assessment (NAWQA) Area-Characterization Toolbox, Release 2.0, U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2010-1268. http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2010/1268.

srcinfo.srccontr: HUC-10 boundaries used in data calculations.

citeinfo.title: Mapping enhanced grazing potential based on the NAWQA Wall-to-wall Anthropogenic Land-use Trends (NWALT) product, 1974-2012

srcinfo.srccontr: Source dataset from which land use for 1974-2012 were derived

procstep.procdesc: (1) Source data from NWALT were based on Falcone (2016).

(2) Source data for masking riparian calculations are based on an NHDPlus V2.1-derived (McKay and others, 2012) grid produced by Richard Moore of the USGS NHDPlus team (Richard Moore, written commun., October 2016). This grid, entitled natflodistdwn, is a 30-m mapping of distance to the nearest networked flowline or water body in NHDPlus V2.1 (McKay and others, 2012). The riparian calculations in this dataset are based on only those pixels with values less than 200 and greater than 0. That is, only pixels within 200-meters of a networked stream or water body are included in the calculation.

(3) Calculations were based on (a) clipping the flow distance grid for all values less than 200 and greater than 0. This created a riparian zone mask. (b) This mask was then clipped against the five NWALT datasets for 1974, 1982, 1992, 2002, and 2012, respectively.

(5) HUC-10 watershed category percentages were then calculated using the USGS NAWQA Area-Characterization Toolbox (Price and others, 2012), based on the 200-mriparian zones within each HUC-10 boundary.

enttyp.enttypl: Attribute Table for land use data
enttyp.enttypd: Data consist of comma-separated text files. There are five tables: landuse_riparian-huc10-nwalt1974.txt, landuse_riparian-huc10-nwalt1984.txt, landuse_riparian-huc10-nwalt1992.txt, landuse_riparian-huc10-nwalt2002.txt, landuse_riparian-huc10-nwalt2012.txt
enttyp.enttypds: Surface Water Status and Trends project, USGS National Water Quality Program

attr.attrdef: Unique identification number
attr.attrdefs: Unique integer ID used for internal processing and for linking data from other tables for HUC-10 data

attr.attrdef: percent riparian zone Water (NWALT class 11), for 1974, 1982, 1992, 2002, and 2012 (year represented by XX).
percent riparian zone Core Wetlands (NWALT class 12), for 1974, 1982, 1992, 2002, and 2012 (year represented by XX). Scale represented by huc10, one of "huc10", "county", or "eco4"
percent riparian zone Developed, Transportation: Major roads, rail and airports (NWALT class 21) for 1974, 1982, 1992, 2002, and 2012 (year represented by XX).
percent riparian zone Developed, Commercial/Services (NWALT class 22) for 1974, 1982, 1992, 2002, and 2012 (year represented by XX).
percent riparian zone Developed, Industrial/Military (NWALT class 23) for 1974, 1982, 1992, 2002, and 2012 (year represented by XX).
percent riparian zone Developed, Recreation (NWALT class 24) for 1974, 1982, 1992, 2002, and 2012 (year represented by XX).
percent riparian zone Developed, Residential, High Density (NWALT class 25) for 1974, 1982, 1992, 2002, and 2012 (year represented by XX).
percent riparian zone Developed, Residential, Low-Medium Density (NWALT class 26) for 1974, 1982, 1992, 2002, and 2012 (year represented by XX).
percent riparian zone Developed, Other (NWALT class 27) for 1974, 1982, 1992, 2002, and 2012 (year represented by XX).
percent riparian zone Semi-Developed, Urban Interface High (NWALT class 31) for 1974, 1982, 1992, 2002, and 2012 (year represented by XX).
percent riparian zone Semi-Developed, Urban Interface Low-Medium (NWALT class 32) for 1974, 1982, 1992, 2002, and 2012 (year represented by XX).
percent riparian zone Semi-Developed, Anthropogenic Other (NWALT class 33) for 1974, 1982, 1992, 2002, and 2012 (year represented by XX).
percent riparian zone Mining, quarries, surface mineral extraction (NWALT class 41) for 1974, 1982, 1992, 2002, and 2012 (year represented by XX).
percent riparian zone Crops (NWALT class 43) for 1974, 1982, 1992, 2002, and 2012 (year represented by XX). Scale represented by huc10, one of "huc10", "county", or "eco4"
percent riparian zone Pasture/Hay (NWALT class 44) for 1974, 1982, 1992, 2002, and 2012 (year represented by XX). Scale represented by huc10, one of "huc10", "county", or "eco4"
percent riparian zone Grazing Potential I (NWALT class 45) for 1974, 1982, 1992, 2002, and 2012 (year represented by XX).
percent riparian zone Grazing Potential II (NWALT class 46) for 1974, 1982, 1992, 2002, and 2012 (year represented by XX).
percent riparian zone Low Use (NWALT class 50) for 1974, 1982, 1992, 2002, and 2012 (year represented by XX). Scale represented by huc10, one of "huc10", "county", or "eco4"
percent riparian zone Very Low Use, Conservation (NWALT class 60) for 1974, 1982, 1992, 2002, and 2012 (year represented by XX).
